Instructions.text: While Concentration Ratio deals with quantity, Enrichment Ratio is a quick dive into the quality of your Concentrate. It gives you a ratio between the amount of precious metal going in and the amount of precious metal going out.
It can be calculated by dividing a metal grade on the Concentrate stream by the grade of the same metal in the Feed stream.
Before we start, take a look at the Feed stream and tell me what is Cu grade entering the Flotation bank
True, and what is the Cu grade getting out of the system (Concentrate Stream)?

The magical act of turning 1% Cu into 2% Cu is called Concentration process, also known as Beneficiation. Flotation is a very common form of Concentration, which can bring the metal grade from less than 1% until 30% or more.
In order to enrich the metal content from 30% Cu to 100% Cu other processes like filtration and smelting are envolved but we won't dwelve into them.

So the job of bringing the metal content from 0% to 100% is called Enrichment and we can see how good we are at enriching metals by calculating the Enrichment Ratio using the formula:

 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Let's try! In a flotation process that the precious metal is nickel, and the Feed Ni % is 2 while the Concentrate Ni % is 6, what would be the Enrichment Ratio?

 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Now check the Cu grade in the Feed and Concentrate streams. What is the Enrichment Ratio of this cell?n
 Enrichment ratio =
Concentrate Metal % / Feed Metal %

Correct. Enrichment Ratio, although a quick dive into the system grades, does not take quantity into consideration, unlike metal recovery. We are going to learn how to correlate quantity and quality in next lessons.
